div.p: BY Vertue of an Order to me granted by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Aſſembled, dated on Thurſday the 28th of Octob. 1680; I do appoint Randal Taylor, near Stationers Hall, to Print this Trial of Roger Earl of Caſtlemaine, and that no other Perſon or Perſons print the ſame.

THE TRYAL OF ROGER EARL OF CASTLEMAINE FOR High Treaſon, In Conſpiring the Death of the KING, The Subverſion of the Government, and Introducing of Popery and Arbitrary Power. BEFORE The Lord Chief Juſtice SCROGGS, &c. At the KING's BENCH Bar at Weſtminſter, the 23th June 1680: Where he was Acquitted.
LONDON, Printed for S. G and N. E. and are to be ſold by Randal Taylor near Stationers-Hall, 1681.

div.head: THE TRYAL OF ROGER EARL of CASTLEMAINE.
div.p:
ROGER PALMER Eſ
que Earl of Caſtlemaine in the Kingdom of Ireland, having been Arraigned at the Kings Bench Bar the Sixteenth of June 1680, for High Treaſon: To which he Pleaded Not Guilty, &c.

On Wedneſday the 23th of June 1680, being appointed for his Trial, the Court being ſate, and the uſual Formalities perform'd, the Lieutenant of the Tower delivered him into Court, and then the ſaid Court proceeded as followeth.

sp.speaker: Clerk of the Crown,
sp.p: Cryar, Make Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Cryer,
sp.p: O yes! Our Soveraign Lord the King doth ſtrictly charge and command all manner of Perſons to keep ſilence upon pain of Impriſonment.

O yes! If any one can inform our Soveraign Lord the King, the Kings Serjeant at Law, the Kings Attourney General, or this Inqueſt, now to be taken of the High Treaſon, whereof Roger Palmer Eſq; Earl of Caſtlemain in the Kingdom of Ireland, ſtands Indicted, let them come forth and they ſhall be heard; for the Priſoner ſtands at the Bar upon his deliverance.

sp.speaker: Clerk of the Crown,
sp.p: Cryer, Make an O yes.

sp.speaker: Cryer,
sp.p: O yes! You good Men that are empannelled to enquire, between our Soveraign Lord the King and Roger Palmer Eſq; Earl of Caſtlemain within the Kingdom of Ireland, anſwer to your Names

sp.speaker: Clerk of the Crown,
sp.p: Roger Palmer Eſq; Earl of Caſtlemain in the Kingdom of Ireland, hold up thy hand. Theſe good Men that were lately called and now here appear, are to paſs between our Soveraign Lord the King and you upon your Life or Death, if you challenge any of them, you muſt ſpeak as they come to the Book to be Sworn, and before they are Sworn.

list.head: JURY.
list.item: Sir John Cutler Knight and Baronet.

sp.speaker: Cryer,
sp.p: O Yes, Our Soveraign Lord the King doth ſtrictly charge and command all manner of Perſons to keep ſilence upon pain of Impriſonment.

sp.speaker: C. of the Crown.
sp.p: Roger Palmer Eſq; Earl of Caſtlemain in the Kingdom of Ireland, hold up your hand.
You Gentlemen of the Jury that are now Sworn look upon the Priſoner and hearken to his charge.

You ſhall underſtand that he ſtands Indicted by the Name of Roger Palmer Eſq; Earl of Caſtlemain in the Kingdom of Ireland; for that he as a falſe Traytor againſt our moſt Illuſtrious and Excellent Prince and Lord, Charles the Second, by the Grace of God of England, Scotland, France and Ireland King, Defender of the Faith, &c. and his Natural Lord; not having the Fear of God before his Eyes, nor weighing the Duty of his Allegiance, but being moved and ſeduced by the Inſtigation of the Devil, his Cordial Love, true due and Natural Obedience, which true and Faithful Subjects of our ſaid Soveraign Lord the King ought to bear towards him, altogether withdrawing, and contriving, and with all his might intending, to diſturb the Peace and common Tranquility of this Kingdom, and to bring and put our Soveraign Lord the King to Death and final Deſtruction, and alter the true Worſhip of God within this Kingdom eſtabliſhed to the Superſtition of the Romiſh Church, and to ſtir up and move War againſt our ſaid Soveraign Lord the King within this Realm of England, and to ſubvert the Government thereof, the Twentieth day of June in the Thirtieth Year of the Reign of our ſaid Soveraign Lord, Charles the Second, of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, King, Defender
of the Faith, &c. at the pariſh of St. Giles in the Fields in the County of Midd. with divers other falſe Traitors, to the Jurors unknown, did traiterouſly imagine and intend the killing, death and final deſtruction of our ſaid Lord the King, and to change and alter and utterly ſubvert the Ancient Government of this Kingdom, and to depoſe and wholly to deprive our ſaid Lord the King of his Crown and Government of this Realm of England, and to extirpate the true Proteſtant Religion: And to accompliſh and fulfil the ſame moſt wicked Treaſons and Traiterous Imaginations and Purpoſes aforeſaid, the ſaid Roger Palmer Eſq; Earl of Caſtlemain in the Kingdom of Ireland, and other falſe Traitors, to the Jurors unknown, the ſame Twentieth day of June, in the Thirtieth Year aforeſaid, with force and Arms, in the Pariſh of St. Giles in the Fields aforeſaid, in the County aforeſaid, Adviſedly, Deviliſhly, Maliciouſly, and Traiterouſly, did aſſemble, unite, and gather themſelves together, and then and there, Adviſedly, Deviliſhly, Maliciouſly, Subtily, and Traiterouſly did conſult and agree, to bring our ſaid Soveraign Lord the King to Death and Final Deſtruction, and to deprive him of his Crown and Government of England, and to Introduce and Eſtabliſh the Religion of the Church of Rome in this Kingdom; and the ſooner to fulfil and accompliſh the ſame moſt wicked Treaſons and Traiterous imaginations and purpoſes aforeſaid, he then and there did Falſly, Maliciouſly, and Trayterouſly promiſe divers great Rewards, and did pay divers Sums of Money to ſeveral Perſons unknown; and then and there falſly and traiter ouſly did write divers Notes, to incite ſeveral other Perſons to accompliſh the Treaſons aforeſaid, againſt the Life of our Soveraign Lord the King, his Crown and Dignity, and contrary to the form of the Statute in ſuch Caſe made and provided.

sp.speaker: Clerk of the Crown,
sp.p:
Upon this Indictment he hath been Arraigned, and hath pleaded thereunto Not
Guilty, and for his Tryal he puts himſelf upon God and his Countrey, which Countrey you are.

Your charge is to inquire, Whether he be Guilty of the High Treaſon whereof he ſtands Indicted, or not Guilty? If you find him guilty, you are to inquire, What Goods and Chattles, Lands and Tenements, he had at the time when the High Treaſon was committed, or at any time ſince? If you find him not Guilty, you are to ſay ſo and no more; and hear your Evidence.

sp.speaker: Cryer,
sp.p: O yes, If any one will give Evidence on the behalf of our Soveraign Lord the King, againſt Roger Palmer Eſq; Earl of Caſtlemain in the Kingdom of Ireland, let him come forth and he ſhall be heard; for the Priſoner now ſtands at the Bar upon his deliverance.

sp.speaker: M. Bonithon,
sp.p: May it pleaſe you my Lord, and you Gentlemen of the Jury, the Priſoner at the Bar ſtands Indicted for High Treaſon; for that he intended to diſturb the Peace within this Kingdom eſtabliſh'd, and to deſtroy and alter the Government, and to bring the King to Death and Final Deſtruction, and to alter our Religion to the ſuperſtition of the Church of Rome, did on the Twentieth day of June in the Thirtieth Year of the Reign of our Soveraign Lord the King, conſult and treat with ſeveral other Perſons, and that he with theſe Perſons, did agree to deſtroy the King and alter the Religion, and cauſe Rebellion; and further to accompliſh theſe Treaſons, he did promiſe and agree to pay ſeveral Accompts and depoſite ſeveral Sums of Money, and did likewiſe write and publiſh ſeveral Books.
To this he hath pleaded Not Guilty. If we prove theſe things, you are to find him Guilty.

sp.speaker: Att. Gen.
sp.p:
May it pleaſe your Lordſhip, my Lord Caſtlemain here ſtands Indicted for High Treaſon; that is, for Deſigning to Murther the King and alter the Government and Law; and this is but a parcel of the Plot, which hath been carrying on a great while, and many perſons tried for it; and ſome have ſuffer'd
and been executed for it. And, my Lord, we will give your Lordſhip Evidence, This my Lord Caſtlemain hath at ſeveral times conſpired the Death of the King, and that he hath reproved perſons for not doing it. And, my Lord, he hath been in Conſults among Jeſuits, where theſe Matters have been carried on, and this whole Deſign hath been negotiated. And my Lord Caſtlemain hath been conſenting and agreeing to all theſe Matters. And, my Lord, when the Trials were in hand, it did appear upon thoſe Trials there were many perſons brought from St. Omers to be Witneſſes againſt Dr. Oates, to prove he was not in England at that time when he ſaid in his Depoſitions that he did conſult with the Jeſuits; and theſe perſons my Lord Caſtlemain had the management and inſtruction of at that time. And all along at the Old Baily my Lord Caſtlemain was preſent there, and did countenance theſe perſons, and was an Interceſſor for them. Theſe are but Branches and Circumſtances, what is material we will prove by Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Art. Gen.
sp.p: Come Doctor Oates, Pray tell what you know.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: My Lord, I have a long time wiſhed for this day; and your Lordſhip may very well remember it. The reaſon why I have ſo much deſired a Trial, is becauſe I thought it a means, and the beſt means, and the only means to ſhew to the World my Innocency, and alſo to ſhew to the World how much I have been calumniated by this Charge.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What have you to ſay? Have you any thing to ſay againſt Doctor Oates?

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: No, my Lord. I only ſay this, here I am a Priſoner at the Bar, and I have pleaded not Guilty, and throw my ſelf upon this Court; and therefore I am very willing to hear what this man will ſay.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I humbly move the Court. Whether or no, I may uſe my own Method?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Give your Charge, we direct nothing.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p:
My Lord, In the year 1677, I was ſent
ever into Spain by the Jeſuits that were here in England; where I remained for ſeveral months, and tranſacted Buſineſs for them; and my Lord, I returned from Spain in November, and brought ſeveral Letters from ſome Engliſh Fathers there; among which there was one directed for my Lord Caſtlemain. My Lord, I did not deliver the Letter to him, but my Lord, the Contents of the Letter were to this effect—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came you to ſee the Contents?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I was at the writing of the Letter, and ſo I did ſee the Contents of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did the Prieſts ſhew it to you? Or did you only ſee it yourſelf?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: No, my Lord; It was ſhewn me by them: And the Contents of this Letter were, That the Fathers in Spain were very zealous to concur with the Fathers here in England in the Deſign, which was the Subverſion of the Government, altering the Religion, and the Deſtruction of the King.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was that in the Letter?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: No, my Lord, not in words at length.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What was, as far as you know, the very Expreſſion of the Letter?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: The word Deſign, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Only that, to promote the Deſign?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Yes my Lord: And under that word we did comprehend all thoſe things, that is, as we uſually took it among one another.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you deliver this Letter to my Lord Caſtlemain?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: No, my Lord, I did not deliver this Letter; but when I went to St. Omers we received an Account from my Lord Caſtlemain of his receipt of this Letter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did you do with it?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I left it with the Provincial, my Lord, who was then Mr. Strange.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was it not given to you to give it him?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p:
It was given me to give the Lord Caſtlemain,
but being then a ſtranger to him, I was willing to ſend one of his own Meſſengers with it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was my Lord?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I can't tell, my Lord, I did not ſee him then. I went over to St. Omers in December 77, or the latter end of November.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where were you when you gave this Letter to the Provincial?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I was in London, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where did you receive this Letter?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: In Spain, My Lord, at Valledolid, of one Armſtrong.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who was it directed to?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: To my Lord Caſtlemain; but I did not then know him, and ſo I gave it the Provincial, my Lord, I went over to St. Omers in the latter end of November or the beginning of December 77, and after I had been there ſome few days, there did arrive a Packquet from London to St. Omers, in which there was a Letter from my Lord Caſtlemain.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: To the Fathers of the Society of St. Omers, in which my Lord Caſtlemain gave them an Account of a Letter that he had lately received from Spain.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How did you know the Contents of this Letter;

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I was Privy to their Letters.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was you acquainted with my Lord Caſtlemains hand?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I will give you an Account of that, I did not know it then, but only as it was generally ſaid among us.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How was it ſubſcribed?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Caſtlemain, My Lord, and ſometimes, my Lord, he ſubſcribed himſelf Palmer.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How many Letters have you ſeen?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Several Letters,

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was this the firſt?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p:
This was the firſt as near as I can remember.
And, my Lord, he gave an Account in that Letter, that he had received a Letter from Spain, and was glad the Fathers in Spain had ſo good an Opinion of his Integrity in the Cauſed

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he ſay from whom he had received it?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I can't remember that, that he had received a Letter I am certain.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know what the purport of the Letter was?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I will give you a plain Account. My Lord, he wrote he had received a Letter from Spain, and that he was glad the Fathers in Spain had ſo great confidence in his Integrity. And, my Lord, in March there came another Letter from my Lord Caſtlemain: for my Lord Caſtlemain had left ſome things at Leige, wherein he did complain of the Fathers, that they made no more haſte for to ſend his things to him; ſome odd things he had left there, and, my Lord, he gave an Account of a certain Letter he received from the Rector of Liege, whoſe Advice he did not like, for the Rector of Leige and the Rector of Gant were mighty Zealous that the Secular Clergy ſhould be perſonally preſent in this Affair.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he write ſo? I would have you ſay what he writ.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I have told you, he gave an Account that he was unwilling to have the ſecular Clergy engaged, becauſe they were a looſe ſort of Men, and of no Principles, and therefore he thought them not fit to be truſted. My Lord, in April there was a Conſult: I came over from St. Omers in April, ſome three or four, or five daies before the Conſult, I am not able to gueſs at the particular time, but it was near upon the Conſult. My Lord, this Conſult was divided into ſeveral Companies after they had met at the White-Horſe Tavern, wherein they did ſome things that did relate to the Order, as to ſend Father Cary to Rome. After that they divided themſelves into ſeveral Companies, wherein they did agree in ordering the Death of the King.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You were by?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I was imployed by them to give an Account of the Senſe of one company to another.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you by when they concluded the Death of the King.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I was then preſent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſign among the reſt?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I don't come here to accuſe my ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You are Pardoned if it be ſo.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I did conſent. My Lord, In this conſult they met together, and an Oath of Secrecy was adminiſtred, my Lord Caſtlemain was there too within ſome few days after the Conſult, that is, the Gentleman whom I accuſe for Treaſon, I ſay, did come, and enquired about the Copies of ſome Letters for to be ſent up into Germany, and did deſire that an Agreement between them and the Monks might be made up, there being a difference between them; ſo that they might have the Aſſiſtance of that Order to carry on the Deſign.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Gentleman was this?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: It was the Priſoner, my Lord, at the Bar.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Would the Gentleman let you hear him ſay, that he deſired Aſſiſtance to carry on the Deſign, and you a ſtranger to him?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I do not think I was a ſtranger to him ſo much as he was a ſtranger to me, he knew I was their Servant and employed by them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Would he ſay in your hearing, that he deſired their Aſſiſtance to carry on the Deſign, and you did not know him?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I did not well know him at that time, and I brought ſeveral Meſſages from the Fathers, and from Mr. Langhorn, and I gave them an Account before him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often had you ſeen him?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: That time he was there, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How many Meſſages had you?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p:
I will tell your Lordſhip where I had been,
I had been at Mr. Simmonds's, who was then Confeſſor to the Earl of Aurundel, who is ſince turn'd Proteſtant; Confeſſor to him as he pretended, and we looked upon him to be. And I had been at Father Cain's, who was in Turnmill-ſtreet, and I had been, my Lord, at Mr. Langhorn's in the Temple, and ſome other places which I do not now remember, it is ſo long ſince. So, my Lord, I gave them Account of my buſineſs, and I did ſee that Gentleman, but did not know his Name, till, my Lord, in June.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: This was, my Lord, as near as I can remember in May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: So you did not know his Name till Three Weeks or a Month after?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: No, my Lord, It was in the latter part of June.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: You ſaw him firſt in May?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: And you did not ſee him till after the Conſult? I don't ask you whether he was there or no, but whether you ſaw him before the Conſult was Signed?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How did you come to know his Name?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, In June Mr. Langworth and I were going over Lincolns-Inn-Fields, intending to go to the Fountain in Fullers Rents, becauſe there was a ſort of Drink that he loved, and we were to drink together, it was in the Evening, and ſo in our way as we went, we met with my Lord Caſtlemain, whom Mr. Langworth did ſalute, and then we came back to Mr. Fenwick's Chamber.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: With whom did you come back?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: With my Lord Caſtlemain.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you know his Name?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p:
Mr. Langworth told me, It was the Priſoner at the Bar, my Lord, and the Priſoner at the Bar was giving an Account of ſome Letters he had received out of the Countrey; and Mr. Langworth was giving
him an Account how forward the Rector of Leige and the Rector of Gant were in offering to have the ſecular Clergy engaged with them, and ſome other Diſcourſe they had which I can't remember, but about the Deſign.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did they talk of at that time? You muſt as near as you can tell us what Diſcourſe they had.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I will give your Lordſhip this, They were ſpeaking of the Tranſactions of the Conſult, and how unanmious the Fathers were in Signing the Conſult.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who was ſpeaking of it?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Mr. Langworth and Mr. Fenwick, and my Lord Caſtlemain was preſent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: They did talk of it?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did they mention the particulars of that Conſult?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What was that?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Laying aſide the King.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And what elſe?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: And bringing in the Popiſh Religion, the Catholick Religion, I ſpeak their own words.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And this Diſcourſe they had in the hearing of my Lord Caſtlemain.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, and my Lord Caſtlemain ſaid, Now he ſhould be revenged for the Injuries done to him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I have nothing elſe to ſay of my Lord Caſtlemain, that I can think of at preſent

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Now my Lord, you may ask him what Queſtions you think fit.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Mr. Oates, Repeat your Journey again.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p:
My Lord, I ſay this, I went a Ship-board in April, I returned from Valledolid in November, I arrived in London in November, and ſtaid in London ſome time, and then I went to St. Omers in November or December new Stile or old Stile, I ſtaid at St. Omers, from thence I went to Watton, then, my Lord, in
the Month of March we went to Leige, and returned back again: In the Month of April, we came hither, ſome time before the Conſult, and ſtaid here ſome time after.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: What time were you at Leige, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: In March 77.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: The end of 77.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: No, my Lord, we were at St. Omers again in March.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You returned in March 77/78

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, the Stile doth ſo alter.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: That is before Lady-day?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, it was before Lady-day, we Arrived here in London in May or in April, and we ſtaid here ſome few days.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: When did you come over again, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, it is now Two Years ago or better, and I can't remember every particular time. My Lord, we were here in May.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: I will ask him as many Queſtions as I think reaſonable, and when, my Lord, I do deſire times and he can't tell the times, he muſt tell me ſo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Oates, Anſwer my Lord what Queſtions he asks you.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I will tell my Lord, Caſtlemain as near as I can remember, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Mr. Oates, When was it you came over?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Really it was ſome few days before the Conſult.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: How many days do you think?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Really I can't remember.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you have your Memorials.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Really, my Lord, no.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you any thing more to ask?

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, a great many Queſtions. Were you preſent, Mr. Oates, pray, at that Conſult, when I conſented to the Kings Death? Was you by?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I was preſent at the Conſult; but I do not charge you to be at the Conſult.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He asks you where it was he agreed to it?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: At Mr. Fenwick's Chamber, I remember it was about Seven or Eight a Clock that we were going over Lincolns-Inn-Fields.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long might you be at Fenwicks?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: It was about 11 or 12 a Clock I came away.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: When you met me in Lincolns-Inn-Fields, was I in a Coach or on Foot, or was any body with me?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I can't ſay whether your Lordſhip had a Man with you, or no.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was there any body with him?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I did not take notice of that.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You were two hours together, pray let me ask you this Queſtion, What was your Diſcourſe about?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: That was part of the Diſcourſe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What? You have given us a very ſhort Account of it in Four lines: You were two hours together, What was the main of your Diſcourſe about?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I will give you as plainly as I can, the Diſcourſe at that time.

sp.speaker: C. L. J.
sp.p: Pray let us know what the main of your Diſcourſe was about.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: One part of their Diſcourſe was about the Revenues of their Colledges, and how they had ſuffer'd by the French's taking St. Omers, and what loſſes they had ſuſtained by reaſon of the change of Government by the Conqueſt; for the Crown of Spain had entailed on the Colledge of St. Omers Five or Six Hundred a Year, for the maintaining the Foundation of their Houſe, or Foundation Rent, and it was taken away by reaſon of the Conqueſt that France had made over the Spaniſh Dominions there; and they were conſulting how they ſhould Write to Father Le Cheſe to be an Inſtrument to move the French King to reſtore this Annuity, that was a Settlement entailed upon it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came you into this Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: This was after the other Diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came you to Diſcourſe this Affair here in England?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I will tell your Lordſhip as near as I can remember: When we met in Lincolns-Inn-Fields, Mr. Langworth recommended me to my Lord Caſtlemain, and bad me take notice of him. I can't ſay this is my Lord Caſtlemain, but this is that Man I ſaw.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he call him by his Name?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: He told him that I was ſuch a one, and that I was ſerviceable to them. And upon our way as we went to Mr. Fenwick's Chamber, he inquired into the Cauſes of my coming over ſo ſoon again, for he ſaid I went over but laſt Month. Said he, How came it to paſs he came over ſo ſoon again? Saith he, We wanted him to do ſome buſineſs for us. And there were more particulars of the Tranſactions of the Conſult mentioned to my Lord Caſtlemain.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How did they bring in the Particulars of that Deſign?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: This is as near as I can remember.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came they to talk of laying aſide the King and bringing in the Catholick Religion?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, After they had given an Account of the Tranſactions of the Conſult: This was one part of the Conſult.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray how came they to bring it in, in Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, they ſpake of the particulars of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I wonder what introduced the particulars: Was it to acquaint him with thoſe particulars?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I have nothing to ſay to that, they were things ſo generally talked of by thoſe of the Jeſuitical party, that when ever they met, they ſcarce did talk of any thing elſe but of that, and ſo they did at this time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray tell me the whole diſcourſe, as you can remember, that relates to this time.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p:
My Lord, I have told your Lordſhip, we met with my Lord Caſtlemain in Lincolns-Inn-Fields. I have told you, my Lord, that we went to Mr. Fenwicks, I have told you, my Lord, that after ſome
Diſcourſe (how it was introduced; I cannot be poſitive, but as near as I can remember) they were ſpeaking of my going over and coming again ſo ſoon, my going from the Conſult to St. Omers and returning again into England ſo ſoon, and ſo one word brought in another.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you know then that my Lord Caſtlemain had ever heard of this matter before?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I don't know; but I am morally certain as to my ſelf; but I can't ſwear he did?

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Did he ſpeak of it to him as a ſtranger to it?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: By the Letter you ſpake of he knew before.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Anſwer my Brother's Queſtion, Was the Letter you had ſeen, before or after that Diſcourſe at Fenwicks?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, that was after the Conſult.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then you know he did know of the Deſign?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I think not of the particulars of the Deſign.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That is, he knew of this Deſign for the main. When you talk of the Deſign you always mean the Conſult?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: No, my Lord, when we ſay the Conſult, we mean what was agreed on at that Conſult, not concerning theſe matters that were done Six Months before.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Oates, Tell me when you mention the Deſign and the Conſult. Do not you alwaies mean the Death of the King and the bringing in Popery?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, but the terms are not convertible: For, my Lord, when we ſay the Conſult, there was ſomething elſe done, my Lord, as that Conſult which had not an abſolute Relation to the Deſign, and of that I will give your Lordſhip one inſtance, as the ſending Father Cary to Rome, which they did in ſome Three Years.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Some trivial matters concerning their own Government, but the thing you talk of is the ſame Conſult and Deſign.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: When I ſpeak of the word Deſign, it was ſo taken among us, and ſo received by my Lord Caſtlemain.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How can you ſay it was ſo received by him?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Becauſe he uſed the ſame word, and anſwered us according to our Interpretation.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: My Lord, he ſpeaks of the Deſign thus, There was a Deſign for the Killing the King, there was a Deſign of the Prieſts and Fathers for it; but, ſaith he, Afterwards there was a general Conſultation, and this Deſign came to be form'd by this general Conſult, which my Lord Caſtlemain, as he thinks, had no knowledge of till the time they met together in Lincolns-Inn Fields, and afterward went and diſcours'd about it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It is very fair, that he doth not know that my Lord Caſtlemain had any knowledge before the Conſult of this buſineſs; but, he ſays, The Deſign upon which the Conſult was, that he might know, which was to deſtroy the King, and bring in Popery. And he ſays, My Lord Caſtlemain did underſtand this word Deſign in that ſenſe they did; becauſe he anſwered their Letters according to their Interpretation of it. How do you know he underſtood the word Deſign in its utmoſt capacity as you underſtood it?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: When we have our Words, we have our Keys whereby we underſtand them. But I will anſwer this Queſtion to the ſatisfaction of the Gentlemen of the Jury. My Lord, he hath many times ſpoken in his Letters of introducing the Popiſh Religion, and annext it to the word Deſign of promoting the Catholick Religion here in England.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Now methinks you have brought the word Deſign to ſomething elſe than Killing the King.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, The Subverſion of Religion and the Government.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he put in Government? Did he talk of bringing in the Catholick Religion and altering the Government.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: No, my Lord, I won't ſay that.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When we are examining concerning Mens lives, we muſt be careful of their words in ſuch matters.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: One part of my Evidence I have omitted, Your Lordſhip did ask me how I came to know my Lord Caſtlemain's hand. My Lord, ſomtimes we received Letters from him ſubſcribed Palmer, and ſometimes ſubſcribed Caſtlemain, ſometimes ſome other Name which I may not remember; and they were generally received as from him. And I have ſeen my Lord Caſtlemain write, for that Night, as near as I remember, it was Poſt-night.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: At Fenwick's Chamber?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: At Fenwick's Chamber, and my Lord Caſtlemain did write a Letter, ſubſcribed it and ſealed it, and I was fain to go to the General Poſt-Houſe, it was ſo late.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: What did he ſubſcribe then?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: No, my Lord, I ſaw no more than the Superſcription.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then you did not ſee his Name to it?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: No, my Lord. My Lord Caſtlemain did ask, Why he had not Anſwers to ſuch and ſuch Letters? For ſeveral Letters I had ſeen which were not of much moment.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I wiſh you had one that was of moment.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: It cannot be expected, my Lord, that I ſhould have them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: My Lord, ask him what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: You ſay, Mr. Oates, you received Letters from me in Spain.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I never ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: You ſaw Letters in Spain from me?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, I have ſeen Letters in Spain that were from you.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Look you, Mr. Oates, Pray let me ask you a Queſtion, you ſaid this, That you did not know me when you met me at the Conſult?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: What Conſult?

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: At Fenwick's Chamber.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I did not know you at Wild-houſe.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: There you met me firſt.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: There I met the Priſoner at the Bar.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays he did not know you at Wild-houſe, but he came to know you by Langworth in Lincolns-Inn-Fields, and then you went together to Fenwick's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Mr. Oates, Did not you ſay, that at Wild-houſe you did not know me, nor I you?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays he can't tell whether you knew him or no, but he did not know you.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Was I familiar with you?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Did I talk Treaſon at Wild-houſe?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: It was the Diſcourſe of the day, but I do not remember every particular of the Diſcourſe, but I remember what your Opinion was concerning the Rector of Liege and the Rector of Gant.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Was there any thing about killing the King at Wild-houſe?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Really my Lord, I can't remember, I wont charge it there becauſe I am upon my Oath; though I morally believe, as to my ſelf, that there was diſcourſe bad enough there.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Mr. Oates, Pray will you hear me, then the acquaintance I had with you was by Mr. Langworth, and then we went that Night to Fenwick's Chamber, and there we ſtaid very long, and there we had all this Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Look Mr. Oates, Was there any by beſides Mr. Langworth and Mr. Fenwick?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Really, my Lord, I don't remember any body was by, unleſs a Maid might come to fill a Cup of Drink or ſo.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Mr. Oates, Pray Mr. Oates, did you and I ever meet together after that time?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Really, my Lord, I can't be exact in that.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Did you never ſee me nor Diſcourſe with me after that time?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I cannot recollect my ſelf as to that I cannot remember.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He does not remember that ever he was with you afterwards?

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: You don't know whether ever I diſcours'd with you afterwards?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I don't remember.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Very well, Mr. Oates, Look, you, Sir, you don't remember that I ever had any Diſcourſe with you after that time; and no body was by but Mr. Fenwick and Mr. Langworth?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: As I remember.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Was not there another Prieſt there?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: There is no body occurs to my Memory.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Mr. Oates, you brought me Letters from Spain.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p:
I brought a Letter from Spain directed to
• ou in 77.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Was I in Town or out of Town?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I delivered it to the Provincial.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: You went over to Liege; did not you ſee me there?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: No, my Lord, I did not ſee you there, I only went to wait upon a Gentleman that was a Prieſt afterwards, that went to take orders.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Did you not ſee me at Liege?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: You were at Liege, did you ſtay there?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I lay there one Night.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Have you any thing to ask, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Preſently, my Lord.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p:
It is very reaſonable my Lord ſhould queſtion you. You own him to be the Lord Caſtlemain, When was it you did firſt diſcover this buſineſs concern
•• g my Lord Caſtlemain?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p:
My Lord, I did diſcover my Lord Caſtlemain to be in the Plot, the Laſt Seſſions of the Long
• arliament, and I accuſed my Lord Caſtlemain this
• rinity Term was Twelve Months, and my Lord Caſtlemain was committed: for when Mr. Dangerfield
came in and accuſed my Lord Caſtlemain, I brought a Charge a ſecond time againſt my Lord Caſtlemain.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: Did you diſcover all this then?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I did charge him for having an hand in the Deſign in general.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: To the Parliament?

sp.speaker: D. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, to the Parliament.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: You ſay when I aſſented to the Kings Death in Fenwick's Chamber, that I ſaid, I ſhould now find a time to be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, don't put me to mention ſuch reflecting Evidence.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: When you were before the King, you did in purſuance of this ſpeak of a Divorce.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I will give Evidence as to that if that my Lord comes to be Indicted for his Prieſthood.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: My Lord may ask what Queſtions he ſhall think fit.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: My Lord ſays he has ſaid it, and what he ſaid in another place he is not to treat now of.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Suppoſe I can prove him an Ill Man in any place, is not that fit to be ſpoken of here? Since he hath brought the King upon the Stage, and ſince he hath accuſed me before the King and your Lordſhips of a Devorce, I ask him whether he ſaw it?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I will tell your Lordſhip what I ſaid as to the Divorce, I heard it diſcours'd of generally among the Fathers beyond Sea, and this was ſome other part of the Diſcourſe at Wild-houſe; and I heard my Lord Caſtlemain ſay that he had been at great charg to carry on that buſineſs of the Divorce.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: At Wild-houſe?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: At Wild-houſe. Now, my Lord, I took no notice of it, becauſe it was not my buſineſs. But, my Lord, after that there was a Prieſts Chamber that was ſearched, and there was the whole Caſe ſtated; now what is become of the State of that Caſe, my Lord, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: By whom was that Caſe ſtated?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: There was a Letter found, whereby my Lord Caſtlemain ſhould have the matter directed, in order to the carrying on the Divorce that was to be between him and his Wiſe Barbara.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Did not you tell the King that you ſaw the Divorce in Strange's hand?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I will tell you this, I gave an Account to the King, that I ſaw in Strange's hand an Acconnt of a Divorce that was between my Lord Caſtlemain and Barbara Dutcheis of Cleaveland.

sp.speaker: Recorder,
sp.p: My Lord, if he ask too many Queſtions that don't relate to this matter, it is impoſſible to give an Account of every particular.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: My Lords, I humbly ſubmit this Caſe.

sp.speaker: Recorder,
sp.p: Ask him what you ſaid to ſuch a man upon the Ninth of Auguſt was Twelve Month, muſt he give an Account?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He muſt ſay he does not know.

sp.speaker: Recorder,
sp.p: Indeed it is reaſonable that my Lord Caſtlemain ſhould ask him ſome queſtions, and that Mr. Oates ſhould give him an Account.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: My Lord, will you give me leave to ſpeak? If he may ask queſtions about ſuch forreign matters as this, no man can juſtify himſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: This is not ſo mighty remote but uſe may be made of it.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: If he ſhould ask whether he were ſuch a day at ſuch an houſe, and tell him yes, and miſtake the day; any man may be catch'd thus.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: How can a man be catch'd in the Truth?

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: My Lord Caſtlemain may, if he can, catch him in any thing he gives in Evidence here.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: My Lord, if your Lordſhip over-rule me, I will ſay no more. Mr. Atturney ſays I come to catch him, I confeſs I do.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: You ſhould not ask him Forreign Queſtions.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
He asks a plain Queſtion, why do you labour ſo much that he ſhould not ask, Whether he had ſeen the Divorce? My Lord Caſtlemain, I have askt the
queſtion for you, Whether or no he ſaid he had ſeen the Divorce? and he does not remember whether he ſaid ſo or no.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: My Lord, I think with your Lordſhips leave, that he is not bound to anſwer Queſtions, that are not to the Evidence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If ſo be he would come to make Application, it may be well enough.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: I ſay it for the Method of the Evidence, my Lord, that I would not have theſe Excurſions.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: I deſire your Lordſhip that I may ſay out what I have to ſay. I ſay this, that no man in the World that ſpeaks truth can be catch'd, neither will Mr. Atturney ſuffer me to catch him.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: I ſay you have liberty to catch him in any thing that doth belong to the Evidence.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: I come to ſhew you the fitneſs of it to this Affair. He comes and tells you, among other Conſults, of Wild-houſe, and my meeting him in Lincolns-Inn-Fields, the recommendations of Mr. Langworth, and going to Fenwicks Chamber, where we talk'd of altering the Government, and my aſſenting to kill the King: and ſince you have brought the King upon the Stage, I will refreſh your Memory a little, ſince you talk of revenging my ſelf, look you if you did not mention a Divorce to the King and alſo to my Lord Chief Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: My Lord, you are under a miſtake.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Pray give me leave, Mr. Atturney.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: You make ſuch Excurſions into Forreign Matters.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Mr. Oates, you did ſay you ſaw a Divorce, I ask you whether you ſaw a Divorce, and where, or whether you ſaid ſo?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays, he does not remember he ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I do not remember whether I ſaid ſo or no, my Lord, I have it down but indeed I did not ſet my thoughts a-work.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: He hath given you an Anſwer that may ſatisfie you.

sp.speaker: J. • aymond,
sp.p: He hath Papers wherein he hath entred Memorandums to refreſh his Memory, but theſe Papers he hath not by him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then he may ſay he hath not.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: That he hath already, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you any more to ſay?

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: I have, my Lord, if you will give me leave to write down two words.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Mr. Oates, You told my Lords the Judges that I did ſay, I was at great expence about a Divorce.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes,

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: That is very well, Mr. Oates.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Call Mr. Dangerfield.

div.p: [D. Oates was going out of the Court.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: May Mr. Oates go out of the Court.

sp.speaker: Court,
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I will be within call, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: I only ſubmit it to your Lordſhips, Whether or no a Witneſs may go out of the Court?

sp.speaker: D. Oates,
sp.p: I will ſtay then.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Swear Mr. Dangerfield.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Pray ſtay.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Here I am a Priſoner, my Lords, and ſubmit it to your Lordſhips, Whether or no Mr. Dangerfield, who hath had the Cenſure of this Court, may be a Witneſs? Whether or no Council ſhall ſhew reaſons to your Lordſhip, whether he may ſpeak or no.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: You muſt ſhew your Exceptions that you have againſt him.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: My Exception is this, That he was convicted of Felony, that he broke Priſon, and was outlawed upon it. Beſides this, my Lord, he is a Stigmatick, hath ſtood in the Pillory and was burnt in the hand. Now I humbly beſeech your Lordſhips, that you will be pleaſed to hear what my Council can ſay, and then, my Lords, if your over-rule, I ſhall give place with all my heart.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I think it reaſonable, if you deſire Council, that they ſhould be allowed to ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: If your Lordſhip pleaſe, when my Lords Exceptions appear.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: What are your Exceptions, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: That I told you, before-hand, he is an outlawed perſon, he is convicted of Felony.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: When was he out-lawed?

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: In the 27th. Year of the King, and we ſay he hath a Pardon in the 30th Year of the King.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How do you prove he was burnt in the Hand, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: When was he burnt in the Hand?

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Call Briſcoe.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: We bring a Pardon unto that, and that will reſtore him.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: That Record we confeſs, ſhew the Pardon, ſhew the Pardon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Now go to that for which he was burnt in the hand.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Here is a Pardon that extends to them all.

div.p: [The Pardon Read; Decimo tertio die Januarii Anno Regni, &c.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: This does not do it.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, it does.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is that the Newgate Pardon?

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We have had it in the Court.

sp.speaker: Att General,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And Felony and Outlawry is in it▪

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where is that for which he was burnt in the hand?

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: For that we give an Anſwer; he was received to the benefit of his Clergy, and he was burnt in the hand, and his Pardon is after that too.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: So it is.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Then his Pardon anſwers them all.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Now you ſee, my Lord, you think Dangerfield ought not to be a Witneſs, who hath gone through ſo many Pnniſhments, out-lawed for Felony, and burnt in the hand for Felony; Mr Atturney makes Anſwer, we have a Pardon, and by that he is reſtored, as he ſays, to be a Witneſs again. If you deſire Council to ſpeak to this point, Whether or no a man branded and burnt in the hand for Felony, and afterwards is pardoned, is capable of being a Witneſs? I ſee no reaſon to deny it you.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: If there be matter for Council to ſpeak in that Caſe, we muſt ſubmit, if your Lordſhip make it a doubt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I do for my own part; in this I am clear, if a Man were Convicted of Perjury, that no Pardon will make him a Witneſs, becauſe it is to do the Subject wrong. A Pardon does not make a Man an Honeſt Man, it takes off reproaches; and the Law is wiſe in that, the Law will not ſuffer endleſs contumelies to be heaped upon Men, nor to be call'd perjured Raſcalls, and ſuch things. It is only to prevent upbraiding Language, which tends to the breach of the Peace. But in my Opinion, if a Man ſtands Convicted in Court, for Perjury, no Pardon can ever make him a Witneſs and ſet him upright again. But that is a different Caſe from this, we are upon this ſingle Caſe, Whether a Man that is burnt in the hand for Felony, whether a Pardon can ſet him right or no? For this I make more doubtful than the other: for a Man may be, that hath committed a Robery, would be afraid to forſwear himſelf; for though one is a great, the other is a greater Sin, and that in the Subject matter; which conſidered, I think it reaſonable to allow my Lord Council to ſpeak to that ſingle point, That a Perſon being burnt in the hand for Felony, and afterwards Pardoned, whether he is capable of being a Witneſs?

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Then I do name Mr. Jones; Mr. Saunders, and Mr. Darnal.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Very well.

div.p: [Mr. Saunders was call'd, but was not in Court.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Are you prepared, Mr. Jones, to ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones,
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: My Lord, do you except againſt that one particular?

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: I ſtand upon both; his being Pillored and Burnt in the hand.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Will you admit that he ſtood in the Pillory?

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: I know nothing of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I will tell you, my Lord, you will ſee whether it be neceſſary to protract this or no; for your Council will hardly undertake to argue unprepared about this Point, and if the Tryal ſhould be Adjourn'd, it would be very troubleſome. I think it the duty of my Place to diſcharge my Conſcience for you and againſt you as the matter ſhall fall out; and if ſo be that you ſhould inſiſt upon it; and he be capable of being a Witneſs, ſuppoſing it ſo; yet I muſt ſay, you may give in the Evidence of every Record of the Conviction of any ſort of Crimes he hath been guilty of, and they ſhall be Read. They ſay laſt day there were Sixteen, if there were an Hundred they ſhould be Read againſt him, and they ſhall all go to invalidate any Credit that is to be given to any thing he ſhall Swear.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: My Lord, I humbly ſubmit my ſelf to your Lordſhip. Sixteen we have, I bring but Six. You ſhall have them Mr. Atturney when you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: My Lord, if you think it worth you while to put it to Council, to argue, Whether he may be a Witneſs, or whether you think it may be as well for you, ſuppoſing he be a Witneſs, the producing thoſe things againſt him, or the Records of thoſe Crimes that he hath been Convicted of; whether that will be as well for you or no, I leave it to your ſelf to do as you think beſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnal,
sp.p: I conceive with ſubmiſſion to your Lordſhip that he cannot be a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Are you prepared to ſpeak to it now?

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnal,
sp.p: My Lord, I am ready to offer ſomewhat to your Lordſhip why I conceive he ought not to be Sworn: but I deſire firſt that the Pardon may be Read, becauſe many Perſons and Offences are comprized in it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It is a Pardon for Felonies and Out-lawries of Felony in general.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnal,
sp.p: If the Perſons and their Offences are ſeverally and ſufficiently pardoned, then, my Lord, I will proceed unto the other Point.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: The whole is good.

sp.speaker: D. Darnal,
sp.p: Then, my Lord, I conceive, notwithſtanding this Pardon, Mr. Dangerfield ought not to be Sworn, and that no Perſon attainted of Felony (though Pardon'd) can be a Witneſs. My Lord, it hath been Adjudged in 11 Henry the 4th. Quadrageſſimo primo, that a Man Attainted of Felony (as Mr. Dangerfield is) though he be afterwards Pardoned, cannot be Sworn of a Jury. My Lord, the ſame queſtion hath been reſolved ſince, In Nono Jacobi. It is reported in Mr. Brownlow's and Goldsborough's Reports, Folio Triceſſimo Quarto. And my Lord Cook in Mr. Bulſtrode's Second Reports, 154. In Brown and Craſhaw's Caſe, is of the ſame Opinion. He ſays, A Man Attainted and Pardon'd, cannot ſerve upon any Inqueſt, and that by the ſame reaſon the Teſtimony of ſuch a man for a Witneſs is in all Caſes to be rejected.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who ſays ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnal,
sp.p: My Lord Cook.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Men do not ſlight my Lord Cook. Where do you ſay that is?

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnal,
sp.p: It is in Mr. Bulſtrode's Second Reports, in Brown and Craſhaw's Caſe, Fo. 154.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: But you ſhould have brought theſe Books hither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnal,
sp.p: I ſuppoſe Sir they may be had in the Hall. My Lord Cook gives this Reaſon for it in that Caſe, He ſaith, That notwithſtanding his Pardon he is not Probus & legalis homo

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
Mr. Darnal,
sp.p: My Lord Cook puts the caſe there of a Man Attainted. And, my Lord, Induodecime Jacobi, It is reported in Brownlow's Reports, Folio. 47.

sp.speaker: J. Raymond,
sp.p: Which of his Reports?

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnal,
sp.p: I know but of one ſet out in his Name alone, the other (which is call'd the Firſt Part) is ſett out in his and Goldsborough's Name. I have Mr. Brownlow's Reports here, and if your Lordſhip pleaſe you may ſee it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is the Page?

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnal,
sp.p: Forty Seven, my Lord, The caſe there reported is, The King Pardon'd a Man Attaint for giving a falſe Verdict; yet he ſhall not be at another time Empannell'd upon any Jury; and the reaſon given there is, that though the Puniſhment was Pardon'd, yet the Guilt remain'd.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: That is a very ſhort Note, and not ſo much in the Book as you have mentioned.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnal,
sp.p: I writ it word for word out of the Book, Sir, and I am ſure there is ſo much in my Book. My Lord, in Mr. Juſtice Crooke's Elizabeth, Fol. 686. in Shelborn's Caſe, it is held, that though the King may Pardon Simony, yet he cannot enable a Simoniack to retain a Living.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: The Act doth make him not capable.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnal,
sp.p: I conceive, Sir, it is upon the ſame reaſon, becauſe the Pardon cannot take away the Guilt, though it may the Puniſhment of the Offence.

sp.speaker: J. Raymond,
sp.p: He can't diſpenſe with Simony, he can't give a diſpenſation to take a Living.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnal,
sp.p: My Lord, upon theſe Reſolutions and the reaſon of them, I humbly ſubmit it to your Lordſhip, whether Mr. Dangerfield (having been Attainted of Felony, though he be ſince Pardon'd) can be a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p:
My Lord, with your Lordſhips Favour,
this is quite contrary to the conſtant and general Opinion, and contrary to the conſtant Practice: For, my Lord, with your Lordſhips Favour, when a Man is Pardon'd for any Crime, if a Man can't ſay he is a Felon, or he is Perjured, then he can't be reckoned ſo to any intent or purpoſe whatſoever.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I told you before it is conſonant to all the Reaſon and Law in the World, that a Pardon ſhould ſtop Mens Mouths from reviling ſpeeches that ſignifie nothing: but it is one thing to ſay men ſhall not go reviling, that can have no conſequent good, but which tends to the Breach of the Peace, and another thing to ſay he ſhall be Liber.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: My Lord, when the King gives him a Pardon, it is as if he had never committed the Offence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He may be outlawed, notwithſtanding the Kings Pardon, and then it is not as if he had never committed the Offence.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: It reſtores him to wage battle, and it makes him Liber & legalis homo: for if a man may wage battle, he is Liber & legalis homo.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Then, my Lord, if he be ſo, he ſhall be a Witneſs: For my Lord, in the Point of Perjury, a man that after a Conviction of Perjury had a Pardon, hath been admitted ſeveral times.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was the Exception taken, Mr. Atturney?

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, and he rejected before he had a Pardon.

sp.speaker: J. Raymond,
sp.p: How many Men have been Witneſſes that have been convicted of Felonies, after the Kings have Pardon'd them?

sp.speaker: Recorder,
sp.p: I will not adventure to ſay that there hath been a particular Objection made, and ſo that the Court hath had the Debate of it: but I will undertake to give your Lordſhip ſeveral inſtances of Men that have been Convicted, and the Judges ſitting there knew them to be ſo Convicted, and did not take notice of it.

sp.speaker: J. Raymond,
sp.p: I ſpeak of Witheringon particularly?

sp.speaker: Recorder,
sp.p: He was a Witneſs, though every man did know that Witherington was Convicted. I begg your Lordſhips leaves to ſpeak it, that the Judges themſelves did know that he was Convicted and had received Sentence of Death.

sp.speaker: Sir F. W.
sp.p: The conſtant Practices of the Judges is a mighty Concluſion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What think you, Mr. Atturney, if a Man be Convicted of Felony, and afterwards hath a General Pardon, is he a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Yes, truly, my Lord, it ſignifies the ſame thing, my Lord, as to be a Freeman again.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: He cannot be of a Jury, if he be Attainted of Felony, and the reaſon is becauſe he is not Probus & legalis homo: and why he ſhould not as well be of a Jury as a Witneſs I cannot underſtand.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: There is a great deal of difference, my Lord, a great many Men may be admitted to be Witneſſes that cannot be admitted to be Jury men.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: Shew me any man that is excluded from a Jury and admitted to be a Witneſs, except in the caſe of Kindred.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: An hundred.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Shew me any Man who being of a Jury was excluded, and yet made a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: A Villian was not admitted to be a Jury man, but a Villain was always to be a Witneſs, and that was a point of Infamy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Infamy was contain'd in being a Villain?

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: He was a Criminal, he was not Liber homo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But though he be not a Freeman, he may be an honeſt man.

sp.speaker: Recorder,
sp.p: My Lord Hobart ſays, A Pardon takes away the Guilt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It takes away Guilt ſo far as he ſhall never be queſtioned; but it does not ſet a Man as if he had neuer Offended. It cannot in reaſon be ſaid, a Man guilty of Perjury is as Innocent as if he had never been Perjured.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: I ſay if a Man be Pardoned he is as if he were not Guilty.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If I were in my Lord Caſtlemain's Caſe, I would ſubmit it; but when he hath given his Teſtimony, my Lord ſhall have liberty to give in the Records againſt him of what Crimes he hath committed.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: I do confeſs indeed that my Lord Hales in his little Book of the Pleas of the Crown, ſaith, That a Man that hath had the benefit of his Clergy, is reſtored to his Credit.

sp.speaker: J. Raymond,
sp.p: If that caſe be allowed it is a plain caſe, for there is no Man can wage Battle, but he that is Liber & legalis homo.

sp.speaker: Recorder,
sp.p: A Man broke Priſon and therefore he could not wage Battle, he replies the King hath Pardoned me that Felony, and thereupon he is admitted to wage Battle.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: Where there is no Judgment given in the Caſe, and the King doth Pardon a Man, that doth make a very great difference.

sp.speaker: Recorder,
sp.p: In the Caſe of Witherington, my Lord Chief Juſtice did look upon the Records, and afterwards ſaid he was a good Witneſs and was Admitted.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: If you have Law by you I muſt conſent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then you muſt conſent.

sp.speaker: Recorder,
sp.p: There are ſeveral Perſons, who have had Pardons after Robberies, and we are forced to make uſe of ſome of theſe Fellows.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Before Conviction.

sp.speaker: Recorder,
sp.p: No after Conviction, my Lord, I have known a Priſoner at the Bar, when my Lords the Judges have been there; to be a Witneſs. And if the Court had made any doubt, it would have been a Queſtion before this time of day.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: My Lord, if you pleaſe Mr. Dangerfield may be Sworn. If your Lordſhip pleaſes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: My Lord ſhall have the benefit of excepting againſt his credibility.

Then Mr. Juſtice Raymond went down to the Court
of Common Pleas, to know their Opinion.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: Have you any other Witneſs in the mean time?

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: No, my Lord, he is a principal Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Sir F. W.
sp.p: Beſides the common Practice, here is a Book that ſays, he ſhall wage Battle.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: That is, when there is a Pardon before Conviction.

sp.speaker: Sol. General,
sp.p: But here, my Lord, he ſays the Reatum is taken away, and then it takes away his diſabilities too. The difference can be nothing here before Conviction, and after, becauſe before Conviction there is a diſability, before Conviction he is diſabled from waging Battle: So that that makes no difference before Conviction, and other Caſes after Conviction, and the diſability is taken away by the Pardon, and he is reſtored to be a Freeman.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: There is a diſability upon Preſumption, tho not upon Conviction.

sp.speaker: Sol. General,
sp.p: There is the ſame legal impediment in the one as in the other: but his Credit is left to the Breaſt of the Jury.

sp.speaker: Recorder,
sp.p: When a Pardon comes, it takes away not only Poenam but Reatum, and the Reaſon my Lord Hobart gives.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Nay give your Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Recorder,
sp.p: For Felony is Contra Coronam & Dignitatem, is a Fault againſt the King, and when the King Pardons it, it ceaſes; and in another place it is ſaid, It Pardons all diſabilities incident to him.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: That is before Conviction ſtill.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Don't my Lord Cook tell you expreſly, That the taking a Pardon doth not prove any Offence? You take a Pardon, it ought not to be concluded that you are Guilty; but the proper concluſion of a Wiſe Man is, that you would be ſafe: It can't be thought that every Man that hath a Pardon in England is guilty of all thoſe Offences that are there Pardoned.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p:
There is a difference between a General
Pardon and a particular Pardon; when a Man doth accept of a ſpecial Pardon, it muſt be intended that he hath ſome Conſciouſneſs of Guilt, or elſe he would not take it; but he that is Included in a general Pardon, may be clear, becauſe all Men are Included in it, unleſs ſome Perſons particularly excepted▪ and the difference is taken in that very point from accepting a General and a Special Pardon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That the Acceptance of a General Pardon, doth not barely of it ſelf intend Men to be Guilty of the Crimes, is plain, and the reaſon is moſt apparent, for beſides that Men be ſafe, ſo there be times that give a Reaſon why Men ſhould have a Pardon, becauſe no man knows when he is ſafe; Perjury ſo abounds that no man can ſay he is ſafe, and that is a Reaſon why Men ſhould be very willing to accept of Pardons.

sp.speaker: Clerk of the Crown,
sp.p: Here's my Lord Hales's Book about the Pleas of the Crown.

sp.speaker: Recorder,
sp.p: He ſays when the King hath diſcharged and pardoned him, he hath cleared the Perſon of the Crime and Infamy.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: It is ſo no doubt.

sp.speaker: Sir F. W.
sp.p: May we paſs upon theſe Authorities?

sp.speaker: J. Jones, Sir Francis,
sp.p: We are not willing to go about it till it be concluded, for that purpoſe we have deſired my Brother Raymond to know the Judges Opinions of the Common Pleas.

sp.speaker: Recorder,
sp.p: He doth expreſly ſay it hath reſtored him to his Credit, and in Witherington's Caſe he did call for the very Records.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: If it reſtore him to his Credit, I hope it ſhall not blemiſh him ſo much when he is Sworn, that he ſhall not be believed.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We won't have any prepoſſeſſion in that Caſe, his Crimes ſhall be all taken notice of: Is it fit to have Men Guilty of all ſorts of Villanies, and not to obſerve it.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p:
In that very Caſe, my Lord Hobart ſays, A Man may ſay of a Pardoned Man, he was a Felon,
though he cannot ſay now he is a Felon, and now what can be objected to this Caſe?

sp.speaker: Recorder,
sp.p: Things may be objected againſt a Perſon, and his Credit left to the Jury, but the Queſtion now is; Whether he ſhall be a Witneſs or no?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We have Men grown ſo Inſolent, they behave themſelves with that vile Inſolence, that now they take upon them to ſpeak againſt whole Societies of Men; as if ſo be there were any thing in them that ſhould render them better then their former Lives or Natures. Humility becomes penitents, and no wicked Man is ſuppoſed to be penitent, that hath not that; but theſe carry it with that Inſolency, as if they were not concern'd themſelves, when God knows the beſt of them diſcover what they do; by being but parties themſelves.

div.p: [Mr. Juſtice▪ Raymond return'd from the Court of Common Pleas.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I will tell you what my Brethrens Opinions are, he hath put it to them on both Accounts, That he was convicted of Felony and Burnt in the Hand for it, that he was outlawed for Felony, and hath a General Pardon. They ſay they are of Opinion, That a General Pardon would not reſtore him to be a Witneſs after an Outlawry for Felony, becauſe of the Intereſt that the Kings Subjects have in him. But they ſay further, That where a Man comes to be Burnt in the hand, there they look upon that as a kind of more General Diſcharge, then the Pardon alone would amount to, if he had not been burnt in the hand. They ſay, If he had been Convicted of Felony, and not Burnt in the hand, the Pardon would not have ſet him upright, but being Convicted and Burnt in the hand, they ſuppoſe he is a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Sir F. W.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Dangerfield.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: The very Attainder is taken away, and ſo all is gone.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Come Mr. Dangerfield are you Sworn?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Pray tell what you know of my Lord Caſtlemain.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I perceive my Brethrens Opinion is, That if a Man were convicted of Perjury, if there be no Burning in the Hand in the Caſe, that a Pardon could not ſet him upright, becauſe of the Intereſt of the People in the King.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Come, Mr. Dangerfield, are you ſworn?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: Then pray ſay what you know of my Lord Caſtlemain.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: About this time Twelve Month, my Lady Powis ſent me with a Letter for the Priſoner at the Bar, my Lord Caſtlemain.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Don't you know him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, this is the Perſon. And, my Lord, the Contents of that Letter I know not: but his Lordſhip made me ſtay till he wrote an Anſwer, and the Contents of the Anſwer, my Lord, were to this effect: For I return'd with the Anſwer, to the Lady Powis, and ſhe opened and read it while I was preſent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Aloud?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: Aloud, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: To you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: To me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who was there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: Mrs. Cellier was there beſides. And the Contents of this Letter were, This Perſon I like well, and though he be no Scholar, he will ſerve to Inſtruct the Youths as he ſhall be directed. By the Youths were meant the St. Omers Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: Becauſe I know my Lord was employed for that purpoſe. I know his Lordſhip did uſe to Inſtruct the Youths; and it was a common ſaying among them, when one of them was out of his part, they uſed to ſay, I muſt go to my Lord Caſtlemain.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What part?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: That which they were to ſay, and one of them did ſay, I am out of my Leſſon, I muſt go to my Lord Caſtlemain.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did he ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: Before the Tryal, my Lord, and my Lord Caſtlemain went along with them to the Tryal, and his Lordſhip complained of ſome ill uſage that the Witneſſes received there. His Lordſhip was one of the Perſons that imployed me to get Lane out of the Gate-houſe, my Lord, and his Lordſhip ſent me to a Sollicitor of his, whoſe Name was Mr. Lawſon (the Perſon is now in Court) to take an account how far he had proceeded in this Affair. I did take an Account, and I proceeded in it afterwards and got him diſcharged.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came you into my Lords acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p:
That was the firſt time, when my Lady Powis ſent me with that Letter, my Lord. A pretty while after this, in the Month of July, I went to wait upon his Lordſhip at his Houſe in Charing-Croſs, the ſame place where I found his Lordſhip before; and I was to take his Advice a bout ſome Letters that came from one Nevil alias Paine. Thoſe Letters and Liſt of Names I ſhewed his Lordſhip, and he gave his Approbation of them, and deſired good ſtore of Copies might be writ: for it was of conſequence and ought not to be neglected. And ask'd me, Are there working Perſons employ'd in that buſineſs? And ſaid he, Encourage them, and I will pay my part. So my Lord, after there were a great number of Copies writ of theſe Letters, I writ a Letter to my Lord Caſtlemain, to let his Lordſhip know that the People had finiſh'd their work, and that there was ſomething more to be done as a Gratuity; and then his Lordſhip in Anſwer to this Meſſenger (who is here alſo in Court) with a Letter his Lordſhip ſent Forty Shillings for his part. And Mrs. Cellier told me ſhe received Forty Shillings and diſpoſed of it to
the uſe intended; now, my Lord, the Contents of theſe Letters were to the ſame effect with thoſe Letters and looſe Papers which I conveyed into Collonel Manſell's Chamber; and theſe all tended to the promoting the Sham-plot, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray tell me what was the Subject of theſe Letters; what was the ſubſtance of them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: To the promoting the Sham-plot. my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That is a General no Body knows what to make of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: I will give your Lordſhip an Account in particular: The contents of many of them were to this purpoſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were they not all alike?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: The Copies were the ſame, and there were ſo many Originals to draw Copies from.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were not the Originals all to the ſame purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: Agreeable in Point of ſenſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray tell us the purpoſe of them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: The purpoſe was, That ſo many Letters ſhould be conveyed into the Houſes of ſeveral Perſons of Quality in this Kingdom, that were called Presbyterians: for that was the Notion, that all Perſons, that were not for the immediate promoting of the Catholick Intereſt, lay under; becauſe they looked upon that Notion to be moſt obnoxious.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who and where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: In general, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In general, where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: By my Lady Powis and the Lords in the Tower.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you by when the Lords in the Tower did agree to it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: When my Lord Peter and my Lord Arundel did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did they agree to?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p:
My Lord the thing is this, after
they received an Account from one Mr. Paine, I brought a Billet from that Paine; wherein was contain'd a Ground or Scheme of the Presbyterian Plot; ſo from thence it derived its Firſt Name, my Lord: ſo that when I came to Diſcourſe with the Lords in the Tower about it, they called it the Presbyterian Plot; and Mrs. Cellier and the Lady Powis ſaid, This is a Notion that will do the buſineſs, as it is moſt obnoxious, and as beſt to our purpoſe.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: How far was my Lord Caſtlemain concern'd in this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: I have not heard his Lordſhip ſpeak of it under that Notion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray let us hear what you can ſay againſt my Lord Caſtlemain.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: Now, my Lord, ſome conſiderable time after I had gotten Lane out of Priſon, I was imployed by ſeveral other perſons, his Lordſhip was one, and he ſent me to his Lordſhips Sollicitor, that is now in Court. A pretty while after this, and the Letters and Liſts of Names, containing matter to the ſame effect as I told you before, as thoſe in Manſell's Chamber, and all tending to the Credit of the Sham Plot, or the Presbyterian Plot. Now, my Lord, a pretty while after this, in Auguſt, as near as I can remember; about the middle of Auguſt, I went to wait upon his Lordſhip, the very next day after I had been treated withal in the Tower to kill the King, whom God preſerve, my Lord; and his Lordſhip had a Servant then in the Room, and he ſent his Servant down Stairs, and looked upon me with a very Auſtere Countenance: Said he, Why would you offer to refuſe the buſineſs for which you were taken out of Priſon?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: To you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: To me, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who was by?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p:
No body, but his Lordſhip and my ſelf; for he ſent his Servant out before: So he asked me, Why I would offer to refuſe the buſineſs I was taken out of Priſon for? I asked his Lordſhip, What
that was? Said he, Was not you at the Tower yeſterday? Yes, my Lord, I was. Would your Lordſhip have me Kill the King, I ſuppoſe that's the buſineſs. Yes, that is, ſaid he Upon which my Lord fell into ſuch a fury, that I was fore'd rudely to leave the Room, and went down Stairs. I think at the ſame time his Lordſhip was writing the Compendium of the late Plot; for there I ſaw ſome words in a Paragraph that lay upon the Table, which I afterwards ſaw in that Book. There was Ink ſet upon the Table, and open in his Lordſhips hand. And his Lordſhip did uſe in his Diſcourſe to call his Majeſty Tyrant.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you heard him? In what company?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: In his familiar Diſcourſe. As to ask when his Majeſty will return from Windſor? Says he, When the Tyrant pleaſes. And I remember I heard his Lordſhip mention the word Tyrant to Mrs. Cellier at Powis-houſe.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: How came that Diſcourſe about Killing the King? What was the occaſion of that Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Had you refuſed it to my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I refuſed.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did you ſay to him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: I ſaid any body but my King, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſaid, Why did you refuſe to do that for which you were taken out of Priſon? What is that my Lord? Was not you at the Tower yeſterday? Why won't you do it? What is it, my • ord? Is it to Kill the King? I ſuppoſe that it is, ſaith he, That your Lordſhip intends. Yes ſays he, That is it, why won't you do it? That is what he ſays.

sp.speaker: Att. General,
sp.p: That is the Evidence we give.

sp.speaker: J. Jones,
sp.p: You ſay he was very violent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was you ever in his company afterwards.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: No, not after that, my Lord, that I know of.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What kind of fury did he ſhew to you at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: My Lord, he was in a great rage, as his Lordſhip is very cholerick; he was buſtling about, and I knew not what he intended to do, and I was unwilling to ſtand the Teſt of his Anger. His Lordſhip ſeemed by his look to be meditating Revenge.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: I ſay this, After his Lordſhip had ſent his Servant out of the Room, ſaid he, Why would you offer to refuſe the buſineſs for which you were taken out of Priſon? Said he, Were not you at the Tower yeſterday? Said I, Yes, my Lord, I was; Would you have me kill the King? Is that the buſineſs? Yes, that it is, ſaid my Lord very angrily.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: When did you go to the Tower? Was this the next day after it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: The next day after it.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Mr. Dangerfield, Pray let me ask you one Queſtion, Did not I threaten to kill you, or have ſome of my Servants kill you, if you came unto me again?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: One time his Lordſhip ſaw me at my Lady Powis's houſe, and he ſhewed me a very particular Favour. I ſpeak it in the preſence of Almighty God, nothing out of revenge, nor for any ſort of Intereſt.

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: Was I never angry with you but at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield,
sp.p: No, my Lord, I know not or any other time that your Lordſhip was angry.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Now what ſay you, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p:
The Firſt thing I deſire to do, is, here are two Gentlemen gives in Evidence againſt me, the one is Mr. Oates, the other Mr. Dangerfield. Mr. Oates ſays, That he in Spain did ſee ſeveral Letters from me: That when he came over into England, he brought a Letter from Spain to me, that that Letter was given to the Provincial, and the Provincial (he ſuppoſes) gave it me. Now, my Lord, I only deſire this, that the firſt thing that ſhall be done, is, that
you will pleaſe to call Mr. Parker, who will ſhew you what a kind of Man Mr. Oates is. And I am glad, ſince you ſay that Mr. Dangerfield is a good Witneſs, that I can prove that every word he ſays is a lie. And ſo begin with Mr. Oates,

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
sp.p: My Lord, I would offer you a Record, a Record of ſome particular Actions from Haſtings.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Read the Record.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What uſe can you make of this?

sp.speaker: Priſoner,
